session.description: Open Contracting Champions met to share projects, support each other in exploring opportunities and Celebrate Progress.

tweets.content: @AranitaBrahaj: Open Contracting Progress! Challenges related #PPP ( public private partnership) and Concesionary Agrements?#IODC16 #openprocurementAlbania
@MCC_Data: @MCCgov at #IODC16 open contracting, data challenges @ODIHQ w/ @webfoundation @agnieszka_rawa @ezeitler @kathlvaughn @jcmccahill

conference_notes:
• There is no perfect implementation.
  • We have the standard of data quality.
  • We have to be able to use the data we have.
  • Some issues moving data from private zone to the public zone.
  • Use open contracting to gain value for money with the procurement system: efficiency, competitiveness, other procurement systems.
  • Cross country learning.
  • Gaps between the information and the work of the techies.
  • When designing the use cases, there are cool data business tools, OCDS standards, but what are the business questions behind those visualizations? We should work on it.
  • It's really important to catch the real use cases of these dashboards.
  • Make something open doesn't mean that will be automatically used. there must be a communication between sectors, feedback, CSOs, governments, business sectors, etc.
  • One of the big values of having a standard is helping the different countries to see where the gaps are in terms of how their -information management systems gather better data or make sure they are publishing quality data.
  • This framework allows countries to set up a path in terms of publishing data.
  • The importance of not only publishing the data and using open data but getting people to really using it and engage in it.
  • The importance of really engaging different kinds of actors, business associations, CSOs, into exercises that go beyond the typical hackathon. Building the capacity for people to really understand this data and give feedback to the government.
  • Looking for an alternative use of data including the government itself so that the government can use this data for better decision making.
name: Open Contracting. Progress, Challenges, Innovation
